name: Chapter 13: AWS Elastic Beanstalk vs. CloudFormation
description: Flashcards comparing AWS Elastic Beanstalk's simplicity with AWS CloudFormation's power and flexibility.

cards.front: You're deploying an app and want AWS to handle the provisioning, scaling, and monitoring while you focus on code. Which service should you use?
cards.back: Use AWS Elastic Beanstalk. It automatically manages infrastructure tasks such as provisioning, load balancing, scaling, and monitoring based on your code and configuration.
cards.example: Like handing your pizza recipe to a professional kitchen that handles staffing, ovens, and order flow so you can focus on your menu.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics

glossary.definition: A service for deploying and managing web applications with automatic infrastructure provisioning, scaling, and monitoring.
Distributing incoming traffic across multiple resources to ensure reliability and performance.
Automatically increasing or decreasing resource capacity based on application demand.
Tracking the performance and availability of an application to detect and respond to issues.

cards.front: You want full control over your AWS infrastructure and need a repeatable way to deploy environments using version-controlled templates. Which service fits best?
cards.back: Use AWS CloudFormation. It lets you define infrastructure as code through templates, enabling repeatable, automated, and safe provisioning of AWS resources.
cards.example: Like writing a detailed pizza shop blueprint you can reuse to build identical shops across the countryâ€”precise, consistent, and fully customizable.
cards.mnemonic: Blueprint it. Build it. Repeat it.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics

glossary.definition: A service that allows you to define and provision AWS infrastructure using declarative templates.
Managing infrastructure through machine-readable configuration files instead of manual processes.
